repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Conservation of Medicinal and
            Herbal Plants Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Conservation of
            Medicinal and Herbal Plants Project (CMHPP) for Jordan were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the CMHPP story should not go forgotten. There have been
            very significant and unprecedented achievements in terms of:
            (i) in situ biodiversity conservation; (ii) sustainable ex
            situ Medicinal and Herbal (M/H) plants' experiences;
            and (iii) dual effect on poverty alleviation and livelihoods
            improvements, and concrete private sector business
            opportunities. When a project has an important
            'institutional building' value and objective a
            community of partners for its continuity, in the case of
            CMHPP it is outmost important that its design is also
            consistent and that approaches and mechanisms are embedded
            that can operationally ensure the result. In addition, such
            investments would largely benefit by involving international
            stakeholders who form part of a broader constituency and can
            act as champions and independent brokers. For CMHPP, an exit
            strategy from the Project Management Unit (PMU) and the
            handing over of direct implementation and coordination
            responsibilities to the National Center for Agricultural
            Research and Extension, Royal Society for the Conservation
            of Nature (NCARE, RSCN) and others should have been planned
            at least during the last year of project operations. An
            investment that is geared at creating a long term thrust out
            of an unprecedented pilot should minimize in its design all
            complexities and avoid over-abundance of objectives while
            privileging only the fewer key components and activities
            that can guarantee realistic and concrete impact. The
            'income generating' component of the project
            should have been more practically positioned in a follow up
            investment. Conversely, a knowledge management activity will
            have been more in tune and would have allowed higher
            cohesiveness and integration among project stakeholders. A
            well designed and implemented monitoring and evaluation
            system is key for any project. This is even more important
            in the case of a project with a 'global'
            conservation/protection and natural resources sustainable
            use thrust. Design and investment allocation need to be
            consistent. In the case of CMHPP this is a lost opportunity.

Jordan - Conservation of Medicinal and

repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Conservation of Medicinal and
            Herbal Plants Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Conservation of Medicinal and Herbal
            Plants Project for Jordan aims to design and test models to
            improve the conservation of medicinal and herbal plants and
            the livelihood of rural communities. An amendment of the
            Global Environment Facility Trust Fund Grant Agreement
            (GEF-TFGA) is needed to increase the costs of activities
            that have emerged as essential for the satisfaction of the
            various project components and the achievement of the
            project objectives: 1) an amount of US$ 100,000 under
            category 1(a) civil works, is needed to cover institute
            management in the Eastern upper slopes (fencing, management,
            and water harvesting techniques). This was neglected in the
            initial operating budget; this amount will also contribute
            to the long term sustainability to promote conservation
            practice as per the GEF objectives; 2) an amount of US$
            300,000 for goods under category 2(a) managed by the
            National Center for Agricultural Research Extension (NCARE)
            is needed to promote certain conservation practices or to
            cultivate herbs on site in order to reduce the pressure on
            wild cultivation on protected herbal species; and 3) the
            sharp increase in fuel prices and maintenance costs for
            eligible spare parts require an additional amount of US$
            50,000 under incremental operating costs.

5087851.trustfund:
TF052299-GEF3 FSP-JORDAN:CONSERVATION OF
            MEDICINAL AND HERBAL PLANTS PROJECT,TF023719-GEF2 PDF B : JORDAN -

5087851.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Conservation of Medicinal and
            Herbal Plants Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Conservation of Medicinal and Herbal
            Plants Project for jordan aims to design and test models to
            improve the conservation of medicinal and herbal plants and
            the livelihood of rural communities. This would be done
            through the management and sustainable use of medicinal and
            herbal plants (M/H) plants for human and livestock needs in
            the Mujib Nature Reserve and the Central Upper Slopes of the
            Rift Valley in Jordan, while ensuring effective in-situ
            protection of threatened habitats and ecosystems in these
            areas. There are four main components. Component 1,
            institutional strengthening, is composed of 6
            sub-components: establishing a project management unit;
            developing links between government agencies, the growers of
            medicinal/herbal plants, the pharmaceutical industry, other
            producers of M/H plant products, nongovernmental
            organizations, and consumers; designing an intellectual
            property rights framework; establishing health and safety
            standards; establishing a national M/H plants database and
            gene pool; and designing and implementing a training
            program. Component 2, the pilot-sites conservation
            component, has two sub-components, namely the in-situ
            protection and management of M/H plants and the ex-situ
            production of rare, endangered and popular M/H plants to
            relieve in-situ pressure. Component 3 consists of
            environmental education and public awareness. Component 4
            focuses on income generating activities, among them, organic
            farming certification, standards for M/H plants for
            harvested products, processing standards for M/H plant
            manufactured products, quality control of M/H plant
            products, product development, market identification, and
            facilitating access to microcredit.

            CONSERVATION OF MEDICINAL PLANTS PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Conservation of Medicinal and
            Herbal Plants Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Despite the positive environmental
            nature of the Conservation of Medicinal and Herbal Plants
            Project, to conserve, and manage best practices for
            medicinal, and herbal (M/H) plants, there might be an
            eventual increase in grazing, and browsing plants due to the
            project's potential success in reversing rangeland
            degradation, obviously with a possibility of overgrazing
            such areas by increasing animal numbers, and, as the
            promotion of organic farming is one of the aims of the
            project, integrated pest management will be part of the
            project activities, with farmers using certain herbicides,
            pesticides, and chemical fertilizers when growing M/H
            plants. Mitigation stipulates the following: capacity
            building, and training will be provided to manage
            environmental protection, increase biodiversity, and improve
            land-use management, and water management; protection of
            wild M/H plants, limited grazing, as well as protection of
            erosion prone areas, and improved rangelands through
            increased uses of perennials; biodiversity will be
            monitored, through agreed plans with beneficiaries to
            promote, protect, and improve stocking of wild M/H plants;
            reserves will be monitored to establish the effect of better
            farming systems on soil, and water quality; management plans
            will be developed to improve rangeland management, and
            demonstrate best pastoral practices; community participation
            will be encouraged to identify wild M/H plant areas, while
            demonstration methods for growing, harvesting, and
            processing M/H plants, and products will be enhanced; the
            establishment of an organic certification will control the
            use of pesticide, and herbicides, thus providing increased
            market opportunities for "organic" M/H plants, and
            products; and, the effects on biodiversity, water quality,
            and carbon sequestration will be measured, and monitored.
